isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE / 9200 9300 9400 MODELS BUILT AFTER JANUARY 1, 1995 - ELECTRONIC ENGINE CONTROLS - CATERPILLAR - 1992 - 1993 - ELECTRICAL OPERATION - CRUISE AND PTO CONTROLS

svcprocinfo.para: The cruise control switches are used as PTO controls (if vehicle is so equipped) when the vehicle road speed is not present (this is an owner selected parameter). Refer to the Owners Manual furnished with the vehicle for operating instructions.

svcsubproc.title: Cruise ON/OFF Switch (195)
svcsubproc.para: The cruise ON/OFF switch circuit (97AE) is an input to the ECM through OEM connector (191) terminal 10. The ground side of the ON/OFF switch is connected through circuit 97-GH to OEM connector (191) terminal 2 (GRD). With the switch ON, the ECM sees 0 volts at OEM connector (191) terminal 10. With the switch OFF, the ECM sees 5 volts at OEM connector (191) terminal 10.

svcsubproc.title: Cruise SET/RESUME Switch (154)
svcsubproc.para: The SET/RESUME switch common terminal (5) is connected through common circuit (97-GD) to OEM connector (191) terminal 2 (GRD). The SET/RESUME switch SET terminal (4) is an input (circuit 97AB) to the ECM through OEM connector (191) terminal 38. SET/RESUME switch RESUME terminal (6) is an input (circuit 97AA) to the ECM through OEM connector (191) terminal 3.
With the SET/RESUME switch in the SET position, the ECM sees 0 volts at OEM connector (191) terminal 38 and 5 volts at terminal 3.
In RESUME position, the ECM sees 5 volts at OEM connector (191) terminal 38 and 0 volts at terminal 3.
In the SET/RESUME neutral position, the ECM sees 5 volts at both OEM connector (191) terminals 3 and 38.

svcsubproc.title: Service Brake Switch (141)
svcsubproc.para: Service brake switch circuit 97AL is an input to the ECM through OEM connector (191) terminal 30. The ground or common side of the Service Brake switch is connected through circuit 97-GB to OEM connector (191) terminal 2 (GRD). With service brakes released (switch closed), the ECM sees 0 volts at OEM connector (191) terminal 30. Applying the brakes opens the switch, and the ECM sees 5 volts at terminal 30.

svcsubproc.title: Clutch Switch
svcsubproc.para: The Clutch Switch is a normally open switch, that is adjusted to be closed when the clutch pedal is RELEASED.

Clutch Switch circuit (97AH) is an input to the ECM through OEM connector (191) terminal 31. The ground side of the clutch pedal switch is grounded through circuit 97-GE to OEM connector (191) terminal 2 (GRD). With the driver's foot off the clutch pedal (switch closed), the ECM sees 0 volts at terminal 31. When the driver depresses the clutch pedal (switch opens), the ECM sees 5 volts at terminal 31.

svcsubproc.title: Vehicle Speed Sensor (197)
svcsubproc.para: The Vehicle Speed Sensor is located at the rear of the transmission. The sensor contains a permanent magnet that creates a magnetic field interrupted by the teeth on the speedometer output gear. As the rotating speedometer gear teeth repeatedly interrupt the magnetic field, a variable AC voltage is generated and transmitted through a 2 wire lead connecting to the Caterpillar Vehicle Speed Buffer mounted on top of the transmission.
The vehicle speed signal (VSS) from the speed buffer is then sent to the Speedometer/Tachometer unit located in the instrument panel and to the ECM.

svcsubproc.title: Vehicle Speed Buffer (193)
svcsubproc.para: The Vehicle Speed Buffer is a Caterpillar component installed by International on top of the transmission. The Vehicle Speed Buffer connects to Engine Harness 5 pin connector (193) and also connects to the Vehicle Speed Sensor through connector (197). The speed buffer receives the variable AC signal from the Vehicle Speed Sensor, processes the signal, then outputs a signal to the ECM and a signal to the Speedometer/Tachometer unit in the instrument panel.

item.para: Vehicle speed buffer output from connector (193) Pin D to the OEM connector terminal 33 is series of 5 volt DC pulses. The frequency of the pulses varies directly with the speed of the vehicle.

The vehicle speed buffer sends a different type signal from speed buffer connector (193) through the engine harness on circuits 47J and 47K, through engine/chassis harness connector (258) to the speedometer/tachometer microprocessor. The output from speed buffer terminals C and E is a series of +8 volt to -8 volt pulses. The two outputs oppose one another. When Pin C is at +8 volts, Pin E is at -8 volts, and vice versa.

svcsubproc.para: With the key switch ON, the speed buffer receives 12 volt operating power (terminal A) on circuit 97AC/97L, from 10A fuse H3. With PEEC III, speed buffer terminal D is grounded through engine harness circuit 11-DF/97-GB through OEM connector (191) and J7 CAT connector and Caterpillar harness to the engine cylinder head ground bolt. With the 3176, the Speed Buffer ground is through circuits 11-DF/11-GD to the cylinder head ground.

svcsubproc.title: Throttle Position Sensor (158)
svcsubproc.para: The Throttle Position Sensor (TPS) is an electronic sensor (acts like a potentiometer) attached to the accelerator pedal assembly. The TPS connects to the cab overlay harness at 3 pin connector (158). At terminal A, the TPS receives 12V ignition voltage (circuit 97L/99E) from 10A fuse H3 when the key switch is in the ON position. TPS terminal B is grounded (circuit 99-G) through the cab and engine harness to OEM connector (191) terminal 2 (GRD).

TPS terminal C outputs a constant frequency signal with a pulse width that varies with throttle position to ECM terminal 40. This output signal is referred to as either Duty Cycle or Pulse Width Modulated (PWM) signal and is expressed as a percentage of throttle between 0 and 100%.

The pedal mounted TPS automatically calibrates to the ECM and does not have an adjustment feature as does the previously used "Beer Can" style remote sensor. If the TPS is not properly calibrated, it must be replaced.

The pedal mounted TPS should produce a Duty Cycle of 10 to 22 percent at low idle and 75 to 90 percent at full throttle. The percent duty cycle is translated in the ECM into a throttle position percentage of 3 to 100%.
The remote mounted TPS is not being installed by International, therefore no discussion is made of that sensor.
